key_points: The trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter in the death of George Floyd, begins with jury selection before the testimony starts on March 29.
George Floyd's death, captured in a viral video showing him saying "I can't breathe" as Chauvin kneels on his neck, sparked nationwide protests and amplified the Black Lives Matter movement.

The House of Representatives passed the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, aiming to hold law enforcement accountable and reform policing practices, including banning chokeholds by federal law enforcement.
Chauvin, 44, has pleaded not guilty to the charges. His attorney claims Chauvin acted as trained, placing the blame on police training and policy approvers.
Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison, overseeing the prosecution, accused Chauvin and three other ex-officers of using unlawful and excessive force, leading to Floyd's death.
The trial will have limited courtroom attendance due to COVID-19 precautions, allowing only one family member of Floyd and one of Chauvin to be present at a time.
Floyd's family expresses disappointment with the limited attendance but looks forward to the trial as a step toward justice and closure.
Bridgett Floyd, George Floyd's sister, emphasizes the importance of being present at the trial to confront Chauvin directly.
Judge Cahill considers reinstating a previously dismissed third-degree murder charge against Chauvin as the trial approaches.
"Operation Safety Net" is launched to ensure order during and after the trial, with a focus on preventing property damage while respecting constitutional rights.
spokespersons: Bridgett Floyd (President and Chairwoman, George Floyd Memorial Foundation)
Ben Crump (Attorney for the Floyd family)
